de.japi.components

Class Japi2Canvas

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • de.japi.components.AbstractDrawable
            • de.japi.components.Japi2Canvas
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable

    public class Japi2Canvas
extends AbstractDrawable
    This class is a simple SWING implemenation for Canvas to match the needs of the original JAPI kernel. It contains a sophisticated repaint strategy to save performance.

    Graphic calls or the execution of graphic primitives (i.e. drawing a circle) on this canvas occur with a specific pattern: for a short time period the graphic primitives are invoked and for the other time nothing is manipulated. It stands to reason that only everytime a graphic primitive is invoked the canvas gets repainted through a Component.repaint() call. But those periods with many graphic calls are very short and contain lots of updates (e.g. see example mandel or canvas of JAPI kernel examples). So if the Component.repaint() method is called every time a graphic primitive is executed the repaint event queue would get jammed. Instead the method triggerUpdate() is called. This method only calls every REPAINT_INTERVAL milliseconds the Component.repaint() method (ignoring how often this method is called) and avoids that the repaint event queue gets jammed. Due to the fact that the last graphic primitive (for a longer time) will be not exactly at the end of a time period, the last changes might not be painted onto the screen. So a watchdog executed another REPAINT_INTERVAL milliseconds after the last graphic manipulation calls then the Component.repaint() method to bring the last changes onto the screen. This call is omitted iff no other graphic manipulation happend in the last REPAINT_INTERVAL milliseconds.

    This repaint management algorithm makes it possible, that this canvas consumes almost no CPU when no graphic manipulation is going on. Through the setting of REPAINT_INTERVAL one can control the CPU load when the graphic gets manipulated. If this number is smaller the CPU load is higher.

      • drawPixel

        public void drawPixel(int x,
                      int y)
        Shortcut method to directly draw a pixel. This method is accellerated in contrast to a Graphics.drawLine(int, int, int, int) call with the same x- and y-coordinates since it writes directly to the underlying raster.
        Parameters:
        x - the x coordinate of the pixel.
        y - the y coordinate of the pixel.
